discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The wording of the question strongly implies that this traffic was flowing fine before the engineer implemented uRPF in strict mode, which also implies there is no ACL blocking the traffic so the answer is A.

Selected Answer: B
It is very tempting to go with A, however I dont see 172.16.3.251 as a prefix that CEF sees.
I dont think we need to assume that this is a result of uRPF strict mode
niether we are aware of an ACL blocking it, nor that option B is clear.
I would go with B TBH

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A is correct. Need to enable loose mode

choices.A: Configure uRPF loose mode to forward the packet.
choices.B: Permit the 172.16.3.251 in the inbound ACL on interface gi0/3.
choices.C: Remove inbound ACL from the interface gi0/3 to allow 172.16.3.251.
choices.D: Configure uRPF strict mode to forward the packet.

The engineer noticed right after implementing uRPF that an inbound packet on the gi0/3 interface with a source address of 172.16.3.251 was dropped. Which action resolves the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is corerct

Selected Answer: A
"IPv6 source guard is an interface feature between the populated binding table and data traffic filtering. This feature enables the device to deny traffic when it is originated from an address that is not stored in the binding table."
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipv6_fhsec/configuration/15-e/ip6f-15-e-book/ip6f-15-e-book_chapter_0110.pdf
Answer correct

questions.question_text: Which IPv6 feature enables a device to reject traffic when it is originated from an address that is not stored in the device binding table?
Which two protocols are used by a P router to transfer VPN traffic between PE routers in an MPLS network? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
P to PE uses LDP and RSVP.

Selected Answer: AB
The key thing here is that they are talking about transfer vpn traffic.
The transfer of the traffic is based on labels so we are not in L3 there, we are in the famous layer 2.5. It's fine that we need IGP between the P routers cause they need to know their P2P links or loopbacks for LDP sessions, but again if we are talking about vpn traffic we are not talking about L3

Selected Answer: AE
I think OSPF is used as an IGP inside the MPLS domain.

Selected Answer: AB
A & B are correct

I would say its A and C

RSVP (Resource Reservation Protocol) is not used by P routers to transfer VPN traffic between PE routers in an MPLS network because its primary function is different. RSVP is used by routers to deliver quality-of-service (QoS) requests to all nodes along data flow paths and to establish and maintain state for the requested service

comments.content: C is used in layer 3. The P routers aren't even aware of the layer 3 VPN. C = Layer 3 VPN.

MP-BGP is used to send extended communities; namely the route-distringuisher, which is appended to the prefix to make it unique.

PE Router;
address-family ipv4 vpn vpnrandomname
send-community-extended (enabled by default on newer IOS versions) 
neighbor 1.1.1.1 activate (activate the other PE router so I send the VPNV4 prefix: RD: Ipv4-Prefix
MP-BGP is update of BGP version 4 with multiprotocol extensions for IPv6 and VPN's
c = MP-BGP is only used by PE routers, the question asks about P routers. Summarizing, C seems incorrect.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
To enable MPLS on all routers in the core, you must configure a label distribution protocol. You can use either of the following as a label distribution protocol:
• MPLS Label Distribution Protocol (LDP).
• MPLS Traffic Engineering Resource Reservation Protocol (RSVP)

Selected Answer: C
Answer is C (LSP)

Selected Answer: C
C is corerct

Selected Answer: C
LDP (Label Distribution Protocol) uses the concept of Label Switched Paths (LSPs) in the forwarding path within the MPLS cloud.

Selected Answer: C
"LDP provides a standard methodology for hop-by-hop, or dynamic label, distribution in an MPLS network by assigning labels to routes that have been chosen by the underlying Interior Gateway Protocol (IGP) routing protocols. The resulting labeled paths, called label switch paths (LSPs), forward label traffic across an MPLS backbone to particular destinations."
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/mpls/configuration/guide/convert/mp_ldp_book/mp_ldp_overview.html

Selected Answer: D
Reference:
https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/ios-xml/ios/mp_ldp/configuration/15-2s/mp-ldp-overview.html

...method of label distribution is also called hop-by-hop forwarding. With IP forwarding...

We are searching for a "Feature".
LSP is the establish a label-switched path.
Option "C"
Answer is C (LSP)

questions.question_text: Which feature is used by LDP in the forwarding path within the MPLS cloud?

line vty 0 4

line vty 0 4

choices.C:

line vty 0 4
transport input all
